instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged
threads.message: Hi, got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with some small corrosion near SMC. I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q5158</TRANSISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R5625</RESISTOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5625</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C5595</CAPACITOR> and there was a burned trace under pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> which i wired to pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R5193</RESISTOR>. After this the fan spins up, stops, then turns on again and keeps running. The machine doesnt boot though, display stays black, no backlight. I have CPU Vcore and clock cycle. Any ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Liquid damaged
threads.message:
In this case should be good to reball SMC.
Is possible to have corroded, or broken balls, or traces underneath.
Did you try to start in SMC bypass mode?
Also inspect <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area, check all SPI Bus Series Termination resistors and clean J6100, if needed.
Be sure to have good solders at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>; does it have 3v at pins 7 & 3?
